publisher: Springer Science and Business Media LLC
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Mitochondrial genomes are the most sequenced genomes after bacterial and fungal genomic DNA. However, little information on mitogenomes is available for multiple metazoan taxa, such as <jats:italic>Culicoides</jats:italic>, a globally distributed, megadiverse genus containing 1,347 species.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Aim</jats:title>
                <jats:p> Generating novel mitogenomic information from single <jats:italic>Culicoides sonorensis</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>C. biguttatus</jats:italic> specimens, comparing available mitogenome mapping and de novo assembly tools, and identifying the best performing strategy and tools for <jats:italic>Culicoides</jats:italic> species.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p>We present two novel and fully annotated mitochondrial haplotypes for two <jats:italic>Culicoides</jats:italic> species, <jats:italic>C. sonorensis</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>C. biguttatus</jats:italic>. We also annotated or re-annotated the only available reference mitogenome for <jats:italic>C. sonorensis</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>C. arakawae</jats:italic>. All species present a high similarity in mitogenome organization. The general gene arrangement for all <jats:italic>Culicoides</jats:italic> species was identical to the ancestral insect mitochondrial genome. Only short spacers were found in <jats:italic>C. sonorensis</jats:italic> (up to 30 bp), contrary to <jats:italic>C. biguttatus</jats:italic> (up to 114 bp). The mitochondrial genes ATP8, NAD2, NAD6, and LSU rRNA exhibited the highest nucleotide diversity and pairwise interspecific p genetic distance, suggesting that these genes might be suitable and complementary molecular barcodes for <jats:italic>Culicoides</jats:italic> identification in addition to the commonly utilized COI gene.</jats:p>
                <jats:p>We observed performance differences between the compared mitogenome generation strategies. The mapping strategy outperformed the de novo assembly strategy, but mapping results were partially biased in the absence of species-specific reference mitogenome. Among the utilized tools, BWA performed best for <jats:italic>C. sonorensis</jats:italic> while SPAdes, MEGAHIT, and MitoZ were among the best for <jats:italic>C. biguttatus</jats:italic>. The best-performing mitogenome annotator was MITOS2. Additionally, we were able to recover exogenous mitochondrial DNA from <jats:italic>Bos taurus</jats:italic> (biting midges host) from a <jats:italic>C. biguttatus</jats:italic> blood meal sample.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Two novel annotated mitogenome haplotypes for <jats:italic>C. sonorensis</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>C. biguttatus</jats:italic> using High-Throughput Sequencing are presented. Current results are useful as the baseline for mitogenome reconstruction of the remaining <jats:italic>Culicoides</jats:italic> species from single specimens to HTS and genome annotation. Mapping to a species-specific reference mitogenome generated better results for <jats:italic>Culicoides</jats:italic> mitochondrial genome reconstruction than de novo assembly, while de novo assembly resulted better in the absence of a closely related reference mitogenome. These results have direct implications for molecular-based identification of these vectors of human and zoonotic diseases, setting the basis for using the whole mitochondrial genome as a marker in <jats:italic>Culicoides</jats:italic> identification.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>
title: Mitochondrial genome sequencing, mapping, and assembly benchmarking for Culicoides species (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae)
